data.text: Contents
Principles of the management of acute onset of severe pain................................6
Introduction

These guidelines are intended to assist clinical staff to provide timely, evidence based practice in the assessment and management of severe pain. Effective pain management is integral to best practice in all clinical care environments
Scope

These  guidelines  apply  to all  clinical  staff  working  in  the  acute  hospital  setting involved in the care of adult patients. For additional guidelines relating to care of patients receiving epidural infusion analgesia refer to guideline 06006. For patient controlled analgesia (PCA) refer to guideline 06010. For children refer to guideline 10045 Acute Pain Management for Children 3 months to16 years.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities
IPMS: development and review of evidence-based guidelines and appropriate training and education across the Trust

Qualified  nursing  staff:  overall  responsibility  for  ward-based  pain  management practice is that of the ward manager. It is the individuals' responsibility to identify training needs and liaise with their senior to address these.
Medical  staff:  it  is  the  individual's  responsibility  to  identify  training  needs  and seek appropriate help, either from the IPMS or their senior colleagues.
Principles of the management of acute onset of severe pain
Principles include:
Thorough initial assessment of the patients' pain;
Analgesic plan, designed to meet the individual patients' need;
Full explanation and shared decision making with the patient;
Prompt implementation of analgesic plan;
Regular reassessment for efficacy;
Changes to prescription if / when required.

The principles form a continuous cycle. Analgesia will need to be changed according to patients' report of pain. This may mean a reduction or increase, change in the route of administration, and / or an introduction of additional analgesics.
Assessment of pain

Pain is the fifth vital sign, and must be assessed and documented on admission. The frequency of regular reassessment is determined on an individual basis: from 30 minutes after administration of analgesia to twice daily where pain is not identified as a presenting issue for the patient.
A standardised Trust observation chart, which includes documentation of pain scores, is used for each patient. This is inputted onto the electronic records system in use.

A scoring system of 0 to 3 is used to indicate severity of pain (see section 9.2). a 0- 10 score is suitable for audit purposes but does not furnish the assessor with useful information on which to base clinical decisions.

Pain assessment on movement yields optimal results on which to formulate analgesic care-plans: when the patient is deep breathing, coughing, and / or moving and not just at rest, or when the patient is asleep.

For patients receiving opioid analgesia additional assessments of respiratory rate, level of sedation, nausea scores, heart rate and blood pressure need to be recorded, and managed symptomatically. If an epidural infusion is in progress / has been used, motor block observations will also be required according to guideline 06006. These can be used to detect and treat potential side effects of the analgesics given.
Pain assessment practices can be used for both clinical and audit purposes.

Patients with potential communication problems may require support with their assessment. For example; children, those with a language barrier, hard of hearing, stroke patients, those with learning disabilities, and those with mental health issues,
etc. Observational assessment tools may be helpful. E.g. FLACC for child assessment, Abbey Pain scoring for cognitively impaired patients. See Safeguarding Vulnerable Adults policy 08034.
Patient assessment
To make objective and unbiased assessments record the patient's report accurately. This enables a meaningful comparison at reassessment.

Neuropathic pain presents with specific characteristics such as ‘shooting', ‘burning', ‘sharp' sensations, and may be dermatomal in distribution. Commonly associated with peripheral and/or central nerve sensitivity it is rarely opioid responsive.

Some post-trauma or post-surgical pain may have a neuropathic element and will usually subside spontaneously. For persistent or chronic neuropathy see Neuropathic Pain guidelines and/or contact the IPMS for advice.
Record the patients' allergies on the prescription chart, medical notes, and affix an allergy alert wristband.

Risk assess for route of administration available, eg if dysphagia identified, maxilla- facial trauma, nil by mouth: consider non-oral route and document in clinical records and on prescription chart.

Record pain, sedation and nausea using the designated measurement tool. This can be found at the back of the Trust Adult Vital Signs Observation Chart. Please see appendix  Determining severity of pain allows correlation with a simple analgesic stepladder as a guide to treatment.
Making an Analgesic Plan
Using medicines to treat pain is a simple first step.

Initial treatment follows the World Health Organization's (WHO) analgesic ladder recommendations, based on escalation and decreasing multimodal medication according to a step-wise approach to pain assessment. See https://who/int. and point 8.7.

A multimodal approach suggests combining analgesics from different groups relevant to specific parts of the nociceptive pathway. Evidence shows this gives an additive or synergistic affect, particularly where opioids are used. Lower doses of opioid are therefore required, which means the risk of side effects from opioids can be reduced.
Appropriate analgesia should be initiated as soon as possible.
Ensure non-pharmacological support, e.g. patient positioning, stabilization of  fractures, hydration, reassurance.
Consider if patient would benefit from:
Epidural;
Patient Controlled Analgesia;
Regional Nerve Block;
Wound Infiltration;
Entonox;
Seek advice and support from IPMS if required.

data.text: *Adjuvant medications are those used for other conditions that also have analgesic properties. For example, some anticonvulsants have shown to be a safe and effective medication that may decrease peri-operative opioid use in patients with more acute neuropathic pain than acute inflammatory pain. When surgery involves more neuropathic-type acute pain there is growing evidence that adjuvant analgesics may decrease the incidence of chronic pain.
See Neuropathic Pain guidelines on the intranet.
Opioids
About Opioids:
Refers to any substance, natural or synthetic, that binds to an opioid receptor;
Three main opioid receptors on which opioid drugs bind - mu, delta, kappa;
These receptors are found in the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nerves;
Preferential Mu receptor agonists produce pain relief;
Can be used in acute and cancer pain, with limited use in chronic pain (ref British Pain Society (BPS) opioid guidance);
Side effects are a limiting factor;
Treat side effects actively.
Possible complications of opioids and action to take:

table_items.text: Ascertain if due to true opioid toxicity Consider other causes If sedation score 2 observe patient closely, reduce opioids if required If sedation score 3 treat as respiratory depression

If respiratory rate less than 8 and sedation score 2 or more Maintain airway, give oxygen via facemask Close patient observation Stop opioid Give opioid antagonist - Naloxone 0.1mg to 0.4mg, titrated to effect Half-life (t1/2) of antagonist maybe < t1/2 of opioid IV Naloxone + consider IM dose May require SC infusion Inform ward doctor, anaesthetist on call and IPMS Opioid analgesic effect will be reversed
Difficulty with breathing, swallowing, rapid heart rate, low B.P, rash. Immediate crash call. Proceed as clinically indicated (Airway, breathing, circulation, oxygen, hydrocortisone, and adrenaline).
Give oral laxative and / or bulk forming agent, plus stimulant if required. Prescribe laxatives on the regular side and encourage oral fluid intake.
Apply calamine lotion topically, give antihistamine; e.g. chlorpheniramine 4mg prn. If severe give low dose naloxone; 100mcg STAT. For prolonged itch see the ‘Itch Ladder' (Burns Guidelines 06009).

data.text: Opioids used in the Trust:
Morphine is the standard drug of choice in the Trust;
Tramadol;

Oxycodone: alternative to morphine, sometimes tolerated when morphine is causing excess sedation, nausea, and / or hallucinations. The oral dose is 50% of the oral morphine dose. Available in intravenous preparation for PCA or via subcutaneous cannula;

Fentanyl: second line drug for use in PCA and epidurals; see IPMS for further advice. Transmucosal lozenges are available for use in procedural pain. Transdermal patches are not commonly used in acute pain;
Diamorphine: used in epidural infusions and for procedural analgesia within the emergency department and Burns Unit. See Guideline 09072 (Intranasal Diamorphine for Burns Patients);
Methadone: contact IPMS if considering;
Tapentadol: IPMS initiation only;
Codeine/dihydrocodeine – not suitable for severe pain;
Ketamine – IPMS team instigation only.
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Non-selective inhibition of cyclo-oxygenase (COX) l and ll, blocks the synthesis of prostaglandins which cause pain and inflammation.
Prostaglandins, however, also protect the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and support renal and platelet function. In turn the side effects of NSAID use may include:
Gastric irritation;
Reduced renal function;
Prolonged bleeding times;
Bronchospasm in sensitive asthmatics.
Use is contraindicated in:
Renal impairment / renal transplant;
Hypovolaemia;
Anticoagulated patients;
Possible active GI bleeding;
Post cardiac surgery;
Neurosurgical patients.
Use with caution in patients who are:
Elderly as creatinine clearance reduces with age
Dehydrated, have a low urine output ( 0.5 x patient weight / hour )
Receiving nephrotoxic drugs: e.g.: Gentamycin, ACE inhibitors
When prescribing NSAIDs prescribe short term only, and monitor for adverse effects or change in clinical status.
To protect against GI side effects:
Consider PPI (protein-pump inhibitor) cover whilst in progress;
PR / IV / topical NSAIDs may still produce GI side effects as they are absorbed systemically.
Avoid I.M. injections
Intramuscular (I.M.) diclofenac is not recommended as painful and can cause abscess / necrosis around the injection site
Asthmatics
Onlyin 5 asthmatics is sensitive to NSAID causing exacerbation of symptoms
Consider test dose under scrutiny if NSAID naïve and not exhibiting asthmatic wheeze
Preparations
Ibuprofen
Ibuprofen has a lower GI and cardiovascular side effect incidence than Diclofenac
Naproxen Diclofenac
Cyclo-oxygenase (COX) II selective inhibitors

This group of anti-inflammatory drugs selectively target the COX ll enzyme, which is mostly responsible for pain and inflammation. By bypassing COX l inhibition the gastro-intestinal and platelet aggregation effects are negated, and they do not cause bronchospasm in asthmatics. Renal effect remains a consideration.
Available on Trust Formulary
Drug   Preparation  Amount  Frequency Paracoxib  IV  40mg  bd
Celecoxib  PO  100mg  bd
Paracetamol
Mechanism of action largely unknown. Effective analgesic. Side effects are rare. Foundation of multi-modal analgesia. By adding paracetamol, opioid usage may be reduced by up to 30%
Prescribing paracetamol for adults:
Maximum 1g QDS;
Overdose >8g per day (delayed onset of liver failure and necrosis);
More effective when given regularly;

Be aware of double prescribing. Check that prescribed regularly and not on PRN prescription also. Check also the patient is not receiving other analgesics containing paracetamol, for example, compound analgesics such as co- codamol;

Paracetamol is poorly absorbed rectally, 40mgs/kg are required to reach a therapeutic blood level. It is preferable, therefore, to use the oral route (soluble paracetamol can be put down a nasogastric tube), or intravenous route, if oral route is unavailable;
When prescribing both IV / oral please use paracetamol stickers as per CQC requirements for the trust.
Contraindications
Hepatic and renal impairment are relative contraindications, prolonged use may exacerbate the effect of warfarin;
Caution when used for patients on enzyme inducing drugs such as some anti- epileptics. The increased metabolism of paracetamol has caused toxicity when less than 8g /day used.
Prescribing multi-modal analgesia
Titrate analgesia against the patient's pain assessment, not against the type of surgery or circumstances.
Pre-emptive analgesia will allow the patient's pain to be better controlled. Therefore prescribe regularly.
Use PRN analgesia prior to extra activity, for example, mobilisation, drain removal, physiotherapy, etc.
Consider the patient's renal and hepatic function.
Consider possible drug interaction with the patient's current medications.
Check for allergies.
Use oral route first, when appropriate.
If  using  opioids  prescribe  opioid  antagonist  naloxone  PRN  if  reversal  of effect required. Titrate according to need.
Actively treat side effects of opioids, i.e., nausea, constipation, etc. Prescribe anti-emetics, and give according to algorithm (Guideline 06004).

Protocol for the titration of oral morphine
Morphine is the standard opioid used in the Trust.
The initial dose is based on multiple factors:
Severity of pain;
Effectiveness of previous analgesia i.e. if 5mg morphine (or the equivalent) had slight effect, increase to 10mg;
Consider whether patient opioid naïve (check for transdermal patches in situ);
Clinical status (e.g. age, respiratory function, renal function).
Drug: morphine sulphate: sevredol tablets or liquid (state which):
Route: PO;
Dose: 10 to 20milligrams;
Other directions: hourly PRN titrated against pain.
Antiemetic and opiate antagonist is prescribed PRN.
Dose and frequency should be appropriate to chosen route of administration: i.e.
Oral = hourly prn,  – 20mg*;
Subcutaneous/intramuscular = hourly prn, 7.5 – 10mg*;
Intravenous = 5 minute intervals, 1 – 2mg* (high dependency areas only). (*normal adult dose)
Monitoring of pain and nausea score, sedation level and respiratory rate are recorded. Side effects are treated promptly and further analgesic needs are based on assessment and evaluation.
Protocol for the titration of Intramuscular/subcutaneous morphine
This can be used where PCA / epidural infusion are not appropriate or cannot be used at the time.
A y-cannula should be inserted into muscle or subcutaneous tissue:  preferred site – deltoid. Intravenous access to be obtained.

Please refer to the IPMS for help with these patients.
Patient involvement
All patients should be encouraged to voice to the nurse / doctor when they have pain.
All patients undergoing elective surgery should have appropriate levels of knowledge and expectations about their postoperative pain relief.
Non elective surgical, trauma and medical patients should be given explanations about their pain management, and realistic expectations explained.
Implementing analgesic plan
When comprehensive assessment, choice of plan and discussion with the patient has been done, implementation should not be delayed.

All patients should be managed in a clinical area where the level of nursing  surveillance and skills, and availability of special monitoring are appropriate for  the patients' pre-existing health, surgical condition and method of analgesia.

If the patient is receiving a PCA or an epidural infusion they should be nursed only in the designated wards and units that have received specialist training to safely manage these modes of analgesic delivery. There is a complete list of these wards available in recovery and via the IPMS.

When the patient's pain is severe and uncontrolled, intravenous (IV) morphine may be required. IV morphine can be given and titrated to effect only in areas where qualified staff are able to monitor the patient closely: i.e. Recovery, GITU, GHDU, Burns Unit. In ward areas IV morphine may be administered by a qualified doctor or member of the IPMS who must remain with the patient to completion of titration and is then satisfied that the patient is safe to remain in their current environment, i.e., patient is rousable, has no signs of respiratory depression or confusion. Patient observation frequency will need to be increased post IV opioid titration.
All prescriptions to be written on the treatment chart according to Trust policy and national legislation.
All medications given must be signed for, and countersigned if necessary, in line With Trust Policy for the Use of Medicines***, national legislation and the NMC Code
A Trust produced drugs formulary and Policy for the Use of Medicines is available via the Intranet.

When prescribing analgesia, consider the most appropriate route, dose and frequency of selected drugs: timing of medication should be considered both to optimise analgesic effect and to avoid an unpalatable mix for the patient.
Review at least daily and alter regime as appropriate. Discharge planning is essential to avoid ongoing use of NSAIDs and opioids without appropriate review.
Reassessing the patient
Reassess the patient regularly for effectiveness and suitability of analgesia.
Document each assessment, intervention, and reassessment.
Discuss management with other disciplines, and seek help / advice when needed.
A minimum of twice daily pain assessments for every in-patient is required, increasing in frequency as required (ie after analgesia or post procedure).
Non-compliance with this policy
Failure to provide regular assessment and effective pain management is a breach of patient rights, and has clinical and non-clinical repercussions:
Patient satisfaction and well-being is compromised
Accountability and professional responsibility is breached
Clinical risk is increased, due to multi-systemic influence of pain
Delayed discharge from hospital resulting in suboptimal patient experience, decreased Trust efficiency and increased risk of hospital-inquired infection
A risk event form should be completed and submitted to the Risk Management Department for non-compliance with this guideline in order to learn from suboptimal practices.
Training requirements
Medical and non-medical staff are expected to understand the need for the regular assessment of pain and the clinical importance of treating pain promptly and safely.

Training  and  education  is  provided  by  the  IPMS  (Integrated  Pain  Management Service), both formally and informally for all clinical staff. The IPMS is available for advice and consultation via the pager system, and through the hospital electronic referral system.
All pain link nurses will be informed of updated guidelines at regular meetings for them to disseminate to their areas / wards.
Registered nurses receive induction training on taking up a post within the hospital, and 2 yearly updates thereafter on pain management.
Medical staff will be informed of revised guidelines via senior medical staff IPMS at audit meetings and twice yearly teaching sessions for all FY1 and FY2 doctors.
Corporate services will ensure that the guideline is uploaded to the intranet and the website and notified to staff via Focus.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the IPMS, which is the specialist  group  with  the  authority  to  approve  local  pain  management guidelines.  These  will  then  be  forwarded  to  the  Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the IPMS of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
